HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DECEMBER 18, 1964

Music Events, Pres. Johnson Top Berthel Rejects
Semester Programs at Homewood Vend. Machines
In New Library

Music events, except for President Johnson's speech, drew
the largest attendance of special
events on campus this fall, according to figures obtained from
the Office of Special Events.

Two band concerts were held
this fall, an unprecedented occurrence, but the turnouts for
each concert were a low 300 per
concert as compared to the other
free concerts. The YMCA has
sponsored performances by Ravi
Shankar and Richard Fagan
this year with admission
charged. The sitarist was heard
by 400 people while the pianist
by only 150.

For his "non-political" talk
the President of the United
States drew 7,000 in the Keyser
quad. The Glee Club-Orchestra
Christmas concert (1,400) last
week and the Peabody Chorus
The Barnstormers' production
and Orchsetra concert (1,200) of "Six Characters in Search of
November 22 were next in at- an Author" smashed attendance
traction.
records for a two night stand
In addition, both the Lubeck .(1,850) and a single night
Choir and the Hopkins-Peabody (1,050).
Concert, featuring the duo pianists Antonowicz and Ragogini,
had near 1,000 attendance. All
of these concerts were free of
charge and
all except the
Christmas concert came under
the sponsorship of COSE.

Of the lectures on campus to
date all have had more than
100 attendance with two of particular note: Dr. Harry Bober's
four lectures on medieval art
(700 total) and Eric Goldman,
the first Lion Lecturer, (750).

The Student Council learned
Monday night that there is little
chance that vending machines
will be installed in the new
library.
Bob Weinberg proposed to the
Council last week that it suggest the placement of vending
machines in the new library.
Weinberg told the Council that
Librarian John Berthel had told
him that he had considered installing vending machines but
that he had decided against it.
Berthel promised Weinberg a
final decision in three weeks.
Matt Liang concluded the
meeting by proposing that Bozarth, the Council's "biggest
mouth," according to Liang,
represent the Council in the
YMCA pie-eating contest, scheduled for last night.

COSE Secretary, Nancy Griggs, prepares for the eventual coming
of the Yule Tide by cuddling the usual attendant paraphenalia.

Tau Beta Pi Held
Initiation Dinner;
Prof. Henn Spoke
The Maryland Alpha chapter
Of Tau Beta Pi held its semiannual initiation and banquet
on Dec. 6 in the Faculty Club
and initiated nine undergraduates.
President Lee Middleman introduced Charles Renn, Hopkins
Professor of sanitary engineering, who was the featured
speaker following the banquet.
His speech was entitled "Engineer, The Plow Shear."
Preceding the banquet seven
seniors, two honors juniors and
a graduate of Indiana University were initiated.
The new members of the national honorary engineering society are: Bruce Anderson, Ed
Howard, Garett Odell, Roger
Rosenberger, Mark Scher, Winthrop Smith, and Allan Stankus,
all seniors; and Allen Douma
and Bob Knauff, juniors.
Richard Smale, of the Clas.s
Of 1959 at Indiana, was initiated
for the Indiana Gamma chapter.
He is stationed at Edgewood
Arsenal.
Under the supervision of Al
Rochkind, the honor fraternity
is currently engaged in a tutoring program in differential calculus and physics for any interested students.
Tau Beta Pi has also compiled
a comprehensive list of graduate
schools throughout the country
for prospective graduate students.
"Selection in Tau Beta Pi is
the most important recognition
One can receive as an engineer,"
Dr. Robert Roy, Dean of the
School of Engineering, commented during the ceremony.

Judge and Jury?
The Student Council has received much justified
criticism since the squirrel episode.
The Council managed to take a sober though minor
matter and discuss it in a ludicrous manner for more
than one hour. In doing so, the Council obscured the
serious issue of two freshmen stoning a squirrel under
the weight of the absurdity of its action.
The squirrel issue cannot be dismissed lightly, for
raised some serious questions concerning the
has
it
Gentlemen's Code and the Council. Is the code, as one
callow youth on the council suggested, "what we (the
Student Council members) say it is"? Is the Council
really a judge and jury? Can the Council defend charges
that it is both judge and jury by 'weakly pointing out
that its punishments are merely recommendations to the
• Dean of Students?

Forget the Gayety
Despite frequent charges that Baltimore is a
decadent old city, and the less frequent but better deserved indictment that they don't show many good
movies in this area (excluding Levering Hall), the city
is not culturally vacuous. Cultural deprivation in this
area can only be the cry of one whose real need is enlightenment.
It is unfortunate that anyone should need our
humble illumination to find that not only does Baltimore have a decent symphony orchestra, but also features at various times and places, many fine concerts
and recitals which are advertised on the Gilman bulletin
boards. The Philadelphia Orchestra concerts at the
Lyric are each attended by fifty to one-hundred Goucher
students, but rarely by a Hoppie. Perhaps the difficulty
lies in a campus-bound attitude here.
Go into the city, men! One needn't search long to
find the Baltimore Museum of Art, but it seems that few
of us ever do. And if you are accustomed to making
regular but infrequent forays outside the Homewood,
try something new. Forget the Gay ety; try the Foghorn,
or Center Stage.
The limitations of university life are a figment of
your overworked studying faculties. There's good stuff
outside, for the metropolitan adventurer who seeks and
seizes it.

Happy Holiday
As is annually acceptable at this time the NewsLetter takes time out from the normal course of its
editorial page to offer what we consider to be appropriate gifts of the Yuletide to deserving campus personalities. It is hoped that these comments will be taken
in the light in which they have been intended.
To:
Dr. Eisenhower: Harvard's endowment.
Dean Shaffer: work to keep him in the office the
night of the next Presidential election.
Bob Feibel: a portable tape recorder so that he can
always record his mellifluent tones.
Mike Oidick: Jimmy Lewis.
Dr. Spring: Harris tweed underwear.
Goucher girls: us.
The Oceanography Dept.: Gebelein Hall.
Dr, Dais: The third door, as it were.
Dr. Wasserman: Concordia Discourse.
Larry Drell: privacy.
Phi Gamma Delta: a Howard Maniloff dart board.
Dr. Osgood: war.
Mr. Vane: a salary large enough to allow him to
shop at the bookstore.
Dr. Markert: the job of supervising undergraduate
advising.
John Glascock: the real thing.
Mr. Steinwald: A Mitch Miller sing-along record of
"Dear old Johnnie J. Hopkins."
Major Clay: more rough-riders.
Carl Davis: dehumidifier.
The ladies in Levering: hairnets.
Shelley Earp: a hand and a hall.
Ralph Cann: a pair of swim trunks to wear on his
SAC-paid trip to Bermuda.
The Barnstormers: the News-Letter budget.
People's Court: The News-Letter phone bill.
Dr. Wickwire: world-wide recognition for allowing
the premiere of "Welcome to Manchester."
Sandy Cohn: John Sanborn.
Mr. Berthel: recognition of all that he has accomplished and the ever-filled fount of News-Letter advice.
Dr. Macksey: the new library.
Ross Jones: Pepto-Bismol to go with the sandwiches.
Ron Wolk: the last payment on his waste-basket.
To all Hoppies near and far: Happy Holiday.

Kirou Ballet Superb

i

By WILLIAM KATZ
Russians have claimed possession of many things but there
is nothing of which Russian
ownership is more universally
recognized than the greatest
tradition in b a 11 e t history.
Among the many Soviet dance
companies, perhaps there is none
to stand beside the company we
know as the Kirov, coming from
the city of Leningrad. This company, with which names like
Fokine, Pavlova, and Nijinsky
have long been associated, has,
until recently, been known to

Americans only through legend,
accumulated out of chance bits
of experience and hearsay. On
Monday, the 14th of December,
at the Civic Center, Harry
Baernstein presented the Leningrad Kirov Ballet in a truly
memorable program.
No legend is capable of conveying the magnificence and
power of this glorious troupe.
No telling is forceful enough to
capture the excitement of seeing
the unbelievable appear effortlessly achieved.
As an ensemble, the Kirov has

few peers. When the ladies of
the corps danced the Kingdom
of the Shades Scene from Bayaderka, the stage pulsed with the
movement of exquisite fragility,
the grace that comes of discipline. The women carved the air
into undulating streams and
glided then on their self made
support.
The Grand Pas de Deux from
the second act of Giselle was an
affair of extraordinary convincingness. Natalia Makarova and
Vladilen Semenov endowed the

ELECTRONIC ENGINEERS
MATHEMATICIANS
Let's discuss tomorrow
In science and technology, the accomplishments
of today are but direction for tomorrow. Why?
Simply because resting on the accomplishments
of today is a luxury we cannot afford.
In Communications Engineering, where
others are content to modify, our mandate
is to CREATE.
In Electronic Data Processing Systems,
where others are content to innovate, our
mandate is to CREATE.
This, then, is the philosophy... the crux of
intellectual thought ... at the National Security
Agency—where the concepts oftomorrow are the
problems of today.

So let's discuss the future...
yours and ours
If you are a gifted and interested Engineer or
Mathematician, we have much in common—including
A COMPULSION TO SUCCEED.
Our future is contingent upon a constant input of
new .. and creative ... scientific talent... the
lifeline of any institution. Our success is embodied
in the technical capabilities of our professional staff.
To assure this, scientific employees are encouraged
to pursue graduate studies at local universities
under Agency sponsorship. Your future with NSA
will entail education ... early responsibility . • •
and unusually challenging assignments.
Why? Because ...
• We MUST create completely new kinds of
communications equipments and systems embodying
concepts and techniques THAT HAVE NO
PRECEDENT... antennas, transmitters, receivers
and terminal hardware of a most advanced design.
• We MUST assure the complete invulnerability
of message content through the novel. .. but never
static ... science of cryptology.

MARIESIA STRIATA!
•1

The object of our concern was a
small, wedge-shaped mollusk found in
southern waters where we planned to
lay telephone cables.
Like others of its genus Martesia (of
the family Pholadidae), it is a borer.
Usually it bores into limestone or
some other substance to find a home.
Would it—could it—bore into our
undersea cables?
At the time, we were testing the
performances of proposed dielectric

materials for undersea cables at various
simulated depths, temperatures and
ocean pressures. We also tested for
resistance to marine biological attack.
The testing showed that our cable
covering wouldn't be attractive to
pholads, and in nearly fifteen years of
experience with undersea telephone
cables we have peacefully shared the
ocean bottom with them.
But we had to be sure we could. In
the telephone business, reliability is

everything. We must do all we can to
safeguard service from interruption. No
threat is too small to ignore, not even
that posed by a tiny mollusk.
Right now we've got other problems.
Out in the Dakotas, hungry squirrels
and field mice are nibbling on our wires.
We have to run,

Le Corsair was seen in an

to be regretted as it is not often
Possible to see dancers of the

Most enthusiastic applause of

Two light scenes from The

took them in a serious vein. Indeed, that was an indication of
the unlucky spot in the evening.
We in this town often show
our provincialism, in one way,
by staying away from cultural
events. This is a shame because
It robs us of experience which
nlight mean a great deal to us
if we put ourselves in a position

Later this spring, we can make

cramped development as a pubbc can be seen in the way we

do not notice humor in its

hands. Is it so strange a thing

one has received? Perhaps if
More of us knew how much a
good audience means to a program, we would not be so aloof
When it comes our turn to give

What others have studied to

from the U.S. Army to design and develop a 5-ton cargo
truck for use in tactical military operations. Before the end
of that year, the first test unit had been designed and built.
This new vehicle, called the XM656 cargo truck, was sent
to the Aberdeen Proving Ground for 40,000 miles of testing
r

,was tested against road conditions that might be found
anywhere in the world: swamps... loose sand.., hilly backcountry ... and highways. During the test, the truck carried

and, half the time,towed a 13,000-lb.load:
Outstanding characteristics of the truck's design are its
floatability, improved cross-country mobility, light weight,
reduced need for maintenance and a multi-fuel power plant
that will run on anything from diesel oil to gasoline.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DECEMBER 18, 1964

Music Events, Pres. Johnson Top Berthel Rejects
Semester Programs at Homewood Vend. Machines
In New Library

Music events, except for President Johnson's speech, drew
the largest attendance of special
events on campus this fall, according to figures obtained from
the Office of Special Events.

Two band concerts were held
this fall, an unprecedented occurrence, but the turnouts for
each concert were a low 300 per
concert as compared to the other
free concerts. The YMCA has
sponsored performances by Ravi
Shankar and Richard Fagan
this year with admission
charged. The sitarist was heard
by 400 people while the pianist
by only 150.

For his "non-political" talk
the President of the United
States drew 7,000 in the Keyser
quad. The Glee Club-Orchestra
Christmas concert (1,400) last
week and the Peabody Chorus
The Barnstormers' production
and Orchsetra concert (1,200) of "Six Characters in Search of
November 22 were next in at- an Author" smashed attendance
traction.
records for a two night stand
In addition, both the Lubeck .(1,850) and a single night
Choir and the Hopkins-Peabody (1,050).
Concert, featuring the duo pianists Antonowicz and Ragogini,
had near 1,000 attendance. All
of these concerts were free of
charge and
all except the
Christmas concert came under
the sponsorship of COSE.

Of the lectures on campus to
date all have had more than
100 attendance with two of particular note: Dr. Harry Bober's
four lectures on medieval art
(700 total) and Eric Goldman,
the first Lion Lecturer, (750).

The Student Council learned
Monday night that there is little
chance that vending machines
will be installed in the new
library.
Bob Weinberg proposed to the
Council last week that it suggest the placement of vending
machines in the new library.
Weinberg told the Council that
Librarian John Berthel had told
him that he had considered installing vending machines but
that he had decided against it.
Berthel promised Weinberg a
final decision in three weeks.
Matt Liang concluded the
meeting by proposing that Bozarth, the Council's "biggest
mouth," according to Liang,
represent the Council in the
YMCA pie-eating contest, scheduled for last night.

COSE Secretary, Nancy Griggs, prepares for the eventual coming
of the Yule Tide by cuddling the usual attendant paraphenalia.

Tau Beta Pi Held
Initiation Dinner;
Prof. Henn Spoke
The Maryland Alpha chapter
Of Tau Beta Pi held its semiannual initiation and banquet
on Dec. 6 in the Faculty Club
and initiated nine undergraduates.
President Lee Middleman introduced Charles Renn, Hopkins
Professor of sanitary engineering, who was the featured
speaker following the banquet.
His speech was entitled "Engineer, The Plow Shear."
Preceding the banquet seven
seniors, two honors juniors and
a graduate of Indiana University were initiated.
The new members of the national honorary engineering society are: Bruce Anderson, Ed
Howard, Garett Odell, Roger
Rosenberger, Mark Scher, Winthrop Smith, and Allan Stankus,
all seniors; and Allen Douma
and Bob Knauff, juniors.
Richard Smale, of the Clas.s
Of 1959 at Indiana, was initiated
for the Indiana Gamma chapter.
He is stationed at Edgewood
Arsenal.
Under the supervision of Al
Rochkind, the honor fraternity
is currently engaged in a tutoring program in differential calculus and physics for any interested students.
Tau Beta Pi has also compiled
a comprehensive list of graduate
schools throughout the country
for prospective graduate students.
"Selection in Tau Beta Pi is
the most important recognition
One can receive as an engineer,"
Dr. Robert Roy, Dean of the
School of Engineering, commented during the ceremony.

Judge and Jury?
The Student Council has received much justified
criticism since the squirrel episode.
The Council managed to take a sober though minor
matter and discuss it in a ludicrous manner for more
than one hour. In doing so, the Council obscured the
serious issue of two freshmen stoning a squirrel under
the weight of the absurdity of its action.
The squirrel issue cannot be dismissed lightly, for
raised some serious questions concerning the
has
it
Gentlemen's Code and the Council. Is the code, as one
callow youth on the council suggested, "what we (the
Student Council members) say it is"? Is the Council
really a judge and jury? Can the Council defend charges
that it is both judge and jury by 'weakly pointing out
that its punishments are merely recommendations to the
• Dean of Students?

Forget the Gayety
Despite frequent charges that Baltimore is a
decadent old city, and the less frequent but better deserved indictment that they don't show many good
movies in this area (excluding Levering Hall), the city
is not culturally vacuous. Cultural deprivation in this
area can only be the cry of one whose real need is enlightenment.
It is unfortunate that anyone should need our
humble illumination to find that not only does Baltimore have a decent symphony orchestra, but also features at various times and places, many fine concerts
and recitals which are advertised on the Gilman bulletin
boards. The Philadelphia Orchestra concerts at the
Lyric are each attended by fifty to one-hundred Goucher
students, but rarely by a Hoppie. Perhaps the difficulty
lies in a campus-bound attitude here.
Go into the city, men! One needn't search long to
find the Baltimore Museum of Art, but it seems that few
of us ever do. And if you are accustomed to making
regular but infrequent forays outside the Homewood,
try something new. Forget the Gay ety; try the Foghorn,
or Center Stage.
The limitations of university life are a figment of
your overworked studying faculties. There's good stuff
outside, for the metropolitan adventurer who seeks and
seizes it.

Happy Holiday

editorial page to offer what we consider to be appropriate gifts of the Yuletide to deserving campus personalities. It is hoped that these comments will be taken
in the light in which they have been intended.

shop at the bookstore.

advising.

"Dear old Johnnie J. Hopkins."

By WILLIAM KATZ
Russians have claimed possession of many things but there
is nothing of which Russian
ownership is more universally
recognized than the greatest
tradition in b a 11 e t history.
Among the many Soviet dance
companies, perhaps there is none
to stand beside the company we
know as the Kirov, coming from
the city of Leningrad. This company, with which names like
Fokine, Pavlova, and Nijinsky
have long been associated, has,
until recently, been known to

Americans only through legend,
accumulated out of chance bits
of experience and hearsay. On

MATHEMATICIANS
Let's discuss tomorrow
In science and technology, the accomplishments
of today are but direction for tomorrow. Why?
Simply because resting on the accomplishments
of today is a luxury we cannot afford.
In Communications Engineering, where
others are content to modify, our mandate
is to CREATE.
In Electronic Data Processing Systems,
where others are content to innovate, our
mandate is to CREATE.
This, then, is the philosophy... the crux of
intellectual thought ... at the National Security
Agency—where the concepts oftomorrow are the
problems of today.

So let's discuss the future...
yours and ours
If you are a gifted and interested Engineer or
Mathematician, we have much in common—including
A COMPULSION TO SUCCEED.
Our future is contingent upon a constant input of
new .. and creative ... scientific talent... the
lifeline of any institution. Our success is embodied
in the technical capabilities of our professional staff.
To assure this, scientific employees are encouraged
to pursue graduate studies at local universities
under Agency sponsorship. Your future with NSA
will entail education ... early responsibility . • •
and unusually challenging assignments.
Why? Because ...
• We MUST create completely new kinds of
communications equipments and systems embodying
concepts and techniques THAT HAVE NO
PRECEDENT... antennas, transmitters, receivers
and terminal hardware of a most advanced design.
• We MUST assure the complete invulnerability
of message content through the novel. .. but never
static ... science of cryptology.
• We MUST develop special refinements for
computers and electronic data processing systems
. experimenting with the latest semiconductors,
magnetic film and superconductive devices to provide
new logic circuits and memory units for increased
speed and capacity.
Interested? ... If so, then LET'S DISCUSS
TOMORROW. Representatives of the National
Security Agency will be on campus in the near future.
Check with your Placement Office for details and
dates, or write to:

MARIESIA STRIATA!
•1

The object of our concern was a
small, wedge-shaped mollusk found in
southern waters where we planned to
lay telephone cables.
Like others of its genus Martesia (of
the family Pholadidae), it is a borer.
Usually it bores into limestone or
some other substance to find a home.
Would it—could it—bore into our
undersea cables?
At the time, we were testing the
performances of proposed dielectric

materials for undersea cables at various
simulated depths, temperatures and
ocean pressures. We also tested for
resistance to marine biological attack.
The testing showed that our cable
covering wouldn't be attractive to
pholads, and in nearly fifteen years of
experience with undersea telephone
cables we have peacefully shared the
ocean bottom with them.
But we had to be sure we could. In
the telephone business, reliability is

everything. We must do all we can to
safeguard service from interruption. No
threat is too small to ignore, not even
that posed by a tiny mollusk.
Right now we've got other problems.
Out in the Dakotas, hungry squirrels
and field mice are nibbling on our wires.

Corsair received some of the
Most enthusiastic applause of
the evening.
Two light scenes from The
Gossips and Fairy Doll were delightful comedy but, unfortunately, much of the audience
took them in a serious vein. Indeed, that was an indication of
the unlucky spot in the evening.
We in this town often show
our provincialism, in one way,
by staying away from cultural
events. This is a shame because
It robs us of experience which
nlight mean a great deal to us
if we put ourselves in a position
to receive them. This ballet was
such a rare event that it
shoudn't have been neglected.
Later this spring, we can make
a new start, in this regard, when
the Royal Ballet and the MoiseYev Dance Company come to
Baltimore.
But another indication of our
cramped development as a pubbc can be seen in the way we
express ourselves as a group. We
do not notice humor in its
broadest forms. We sit on our
hands. Is it so strange a thing
to thank a performer for what
one has received? Perhaps if
More of us knew how much a
good audience means to a program, we would not be so aloof
When it comes our turn to give
voice to approval. Both in attending and then in becoming
involved can we receive most
What others have studied to
give.
The program concluded with
the Cossack Scene from Taras
Bulba. A dramatic pageant of
dance and revelry, it was Russian folk dance at its most exciting.

from the U.S. Army to design and develop a 5-ton cargo
truck for use in tactical military operations. Before the end
of that year, the first test unit had been designed and built.
This new vehicle, called the XM656 cargo truck, was sent
to the Aberdeen Proving Ground for 40,000 miles of testing
r
1 —twice that required for military acceptance. The vehicle
,was tested against road conditions that might be found
anywhere in the world: swamps... loose sand.., hilly backcountry ... and highways. During the test, the truck carried

and, half the time,towed a 13,000-lb.load:
Outstanding characteristics of the truck's design are its
floatability, improved cross-country mobility, light weight,
reduced need for maintenance and a multi-fuel power plant
that will run on anything from diesel oil to gasoline.
